steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: You and your co-parent sit at opposite ends of the table. No lawyers, no judges, just two tired parents trying to draw the first clear lines after a difficult breakup.

choices.label: Start with the child’s routine.
choices.text: You say: “Can we start with our child’s routine? Bedtime, school, handovers — if that feels stable, everything else is easier.”

choices.label: Start with your frustrations.
choices.text: You jump in: “I can’t keep doing last-minute changes. It’s exhausting and it’s not fair.”

steps.speaker: Co-Parent
steps.text: They nod slowly. “Okay… routine. I can work with that. I just don’t want to feel like I’m losing time with them.”

choices.label: Acknowledge their fear and suggest a written plan.
choices.text: You answer: “I get that. What if we write down a schedule that feels fair to both of us — so we’re not fighting on WhatsApp every week?”

choices.label: Insist on your own proposal only.
choices.text: You slide your own printed schedule across the table. “This is what I think is best, let’s just sign this.”

steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: The room tightens. Old arguments hover just under the surface, ready to explode.

choices.label: Slow down and bring the focus back to the child.
choices.text: You take a breath. “Look, I’m angry, yes. But I don’t want us to keep fighting in front of our child — or about them. Can we focus on what they need first?”

choices.label: Keep pushing your point.
choices.text: You lean forward. “You say you’re doing everything, but that’s not true and you know it.”

steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: A beat of silence. Both of you know this conversation could still go badly — or become a turning point.

choices.label: Propose 1–2 concrete agreements for the next month.
choices.text: You suggest: “What if we agree on pickup times and overnights just for the next month — and then revisit? Short, clear, and written down.”

choices.label: Say you’re overwhelmed and ask to pause.
choices.text: You admit: “I’m overwhelmed. I don’t want to say something I’ll regret. Can we pause here and schedule another talk, maybe with a mediator?”

steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: You leave the table with at least one small agreement — or at least a clearer sense of what you need next. It’s not a miracle fix, but it’s not another screaming match either.

choices.label: Return to main menu.
choices.text: End this scene and go back to the scenario menu.
